conclusion: Consider forces due to point charges +Q at M and -Q at N to find electric force on ball at B.
Ball experiences two Coulomb forces: F1 from charge at M and F2 from charge at N, both of form F = kQq/r^2.
M, N, and B form an equilateral triangle with side length L.
Distance from B to both M and N is L.
Calculate force F1 from +Q at M: F1 = kQq/L^2.
Calculate force F2 from -Q at N: F2 = kQq/L^2.
Forces F1 and F2 are directed along lines MB and NB, respectively.
Each force has an angle of 60° with respect to horizontal line through B due to symmetry and equilateral triangle.
Horizontal components of F1 and F2 cancel out due to symmetry.
Vertical components of F1 and F2 add together because both are directed upward: F_vertical = 2 * (kQq/L^2) * cos(60°).
Magnitude of net electric force on ball at B is F = kQq/L^2.
Final answer: Magnitude of electric force experienced by small ball at B is kQq/L^2.
